Your time-scales confuse me. (Some of) These traits were lost supposedly millions of years ago, but can re-appear over the course of what seems like a few generations? If we look at your video on evolutionary rescue, specifically regarding cliff swallows, significant changes to limb size can occur within the life of a human observer. Meanwhile, what you are talking about here isn't as much the fundamental alteration of the limb, but a general coefficient change in a handler gene, something far simpler.
Am I missing something here, or shouldn't all of this be a lot shorter in scale?

Dollo's law always seemed like nonsense to me. Random mutation is far more likely to reactivate dormant genes for a feature than to develop similar genes from scratch. If creatures typically don't revert to earlier evolutionary forms, it would be due to the unlikeliness of repeating the circumstances in which that creature evolved. There's also the fact that what we arbitrarily call "complex" features are more likely to be associated with niche specialization, and it's much easier to go from generalist to specialist than vice versa.

Ativisms: since humans are still occasionally born with tails, those of us who feel coming down from the trees was a mistake still have an option to go back.

The selfish gene: genes that are not needed are not deleted, they are just turned off and  are carried forward through every new generation. As these genes do not contribute to the fitness of the individual, mutations may turn them dysfunctional, and they will just become part of the junk DNA in an organism. Because of the size of eukaryotic cells, the energy cost to carry a huge gene pool is relatively much smaller than in prokaryotes. Therefore there is no mystery to the reason for atavism. Eukaryotes do not clean  out their gene library, or DNA records,  prokaryotes do.

One issue I have with scientists is they regularly confuse the forms used to describe and understand a system with the system itself.
Physics is not made of math, it is described by math. Evolution is not created by the theory, it is described by it.

Putting the cart before the horse, putting the effect before the cause, it is a human weakness that I find particularly off-putting. Use descriptions, use classifications, but remember that they are ARTIFICIAL classifications. They are not the rule, they are a generalization we use to help our puny little minds grasp on to the myriad complexities of the universe

It's interesting that male/female dimorphism exists in species across most phyla, even across kingdoms- but the mechanism by which the differential arises is wildly different. X and Y chromosomes in humans and other mammals, ZW in birds, UV in algae, temperature of the nest in alligators and turtles, plants that can change sex... but all these different encoding methods all have very similar results. Only a relatively few species have sexes that are not simply male/female, and most of those are cryptic male/female "impersonators" such as Hyenas. Only a few really odd ones do odd things like Tetrahymena, with 7 sexes and 21 combinations. Perhaps it's just that the simplest binary split achieves most of the benefits with the least complexity that could malfunction.

It would seem long term evolution favors organisms that don't "delete" genes but simply deactivate them and allows for a certain amount of spontaneous mutation to reactivate them. That allows them to adapt to a changing environment. Deleting genes would reduce costs for cell multiplication and be a short term optimization, but it's a local optimum if you consider that all animals constantly had to evolve with the environment or go extinct.
My guess is this is why we don't have 100% cancer suppression because mutations are often bad for the individual but sometimes good for the species and allows them to adapt and survive instead of going extinct.

I want to brag about part of this. I realize half a century ago most reasons why scientist were bugged about evolution and still will do for a pretty good time. My understanding at the time keeps going because those scientists didn't figure it out yet.
First, we give to the word 'evolution' much more meaning than what is due.
Second, most changes in the genetic code of any species is already known and, igf taken one by one, we must realize each of them is the result of a probability about one kind of modification. So, saying at first sight that a mutation result in the lost of a character has many shortcomings. A mutation change the whole code through only a small part of it. So, that small part can be undone by the same order of probability. At the human scale, it is most likely rare or not happening. Since there so many parameters to take into account, a mutation can be anywhere and probably not the inverse of the first one.
I did compare as a young biology student the genetic code to a computer program (at the time I knew only Fortran+, pretty old for most living human today) with its linear code, but with subroutines more or less complex and applicable at many different places alongside that linear code. That is very close to the functioning genetic code. Practice coding or dig into Microsoft / Windows difficulties over their 25 first years and you will have much more insights about evolution, atavisms, mutations...
I didn't say the tenth of what I understood at that time and most genetic discoveries since then are unveilling my thoughts at the time. If you don't like as a brag, forget the first and the last paragraphs and read the remaining again. You'll be on a good track.

At one point the Mecha wipe out the Biotech faction and as a parting shot, the Biotech faction awaken a Primal Gene in many different animals around the world who will gain ancient abilities become compelled to destroy the Mecha when sighted.

A thousand years later a village boy finds a mutated beast of burden who had grown wings and a glowing throat. He disobeys the villages religious tradition of executing these "Heresy Beasts" and dreams of flight so he hides it until it matures.

Eventually the beast is fully matured and he takes it out to fly. Just before they take off an ancient Mecha warship nuke his village and the beast fires an energy beam at it and is compelled to pursue.

The boy and "Heresy Dragon" traverse the world and fight many other Mecha and assimilated Heresy Beasts protecting the ancient Mecha Empire.

Epigenetics may explain this better. Every trait we have is important to survival in some environment. Because environments may change drastically at any time, it would be advantageous for animals to poses and express a vast array of traits. These traits would have some environmental trigger and when expressed would make animals look wildly different than their ancestors. These traits would remained expressed until the environment changed again. The cost of holding onto extra traits that might be needed later is small in contrast to the benefit of survival.

Legs? That's a duplicated flipper gene. Genes are easy to duplicate. That doesn't mean they used to have them. You get duplicated genes to make cows with eight legs.
Just because those limpet species forgot to turn those genes off when they were done being babies doesn't mean they all used to be like that. Dogs keep some of their baby traits, too.
How do you know what these mites have been doing for millions of years? Some animals go back and forth depending on what would be best at the time. Just because they haven't been expressing this gene doesn't mean they don't have it. Genes can turn on and off sometimes.

To me seeing atavisms makes just as much sense as seeing future traits yet-to-be-selected-for. The future-beneficial gene(s) don't exist in any meaningful density before selection and yet we see extra digits that aren't selected for (as an example). To me it then seems actuallly more likely to get a throwback; we've never had a functional sixth digit but whales have had functional hind limbs; their genes have definitely had that capability; a vestigial form of a functional element should be more common than a vestigial non-functional element. Throwbacks then should be less alarming unless there is a strong selection against them... Or am i missing something?
